Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> @Vycid was thinking about your theory of FPGA purchases redirecting funds that people might otherwise use for buying, and it's actually pretty interesting in a couple ways. First, I agree that at least temporarily, until velocity of the money supply evens it out, it is likely to have such an effect if the sellers then sell Verus and keep none. At the same time, one interesting thought that came to mind is which would get you more mining/staking power, an FPGA for Verus or the Verus itself? Over the long run, the answer should be that you would earn more by spending it to buy the FPGA, or someone else is getting the better deal.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Vycid> @miketout yeah, that's an interesting question. I know for sure that the 50/50 split is definitely very supportive of the price. Usually the triple-digit annual inflation rates will sink new coins before they can take off

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Vycid> There's probably some equilibrium point, where the competition over the hashrate reaches a point where it's better to stake. But every time a new generation of hardware comes out (in this case ASIC) that equilibrium is disrupted and you get some capital outflow

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Godballz> That's funny, I was thinking about that too. Staking the same amount of Verus extends the catch up time somewhat. That is a good point you two make, not only are funds temporarily redirected to the device sales but the sellers are going to be converting as well which would have a double whammy effect. Considering this, it isnt too bad a drop and I'll be interested to see as time goes on a likely good rebound effect since things still seem to be holding up pretty well, bear in mind the whole market is a bit wonky at the moment

Author: Gateway#3763

Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Patrick ManBearPig> Buying equipment for mining increases your risk exposure though. Especially specialized equipment. How long will an FPGA retain any resale value? Depends on the market. Also depends on competition. If I buy Verus, I eliminate everything but the market risk.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Emmanuel> what a surprise, cypherpunks not using fiat for their crypto business

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Vycid> @Emmanuel as anyone who runs an ecommerce site will tell you, you want to make the checkout process as painless as possible

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Vycid> You are excluding a lot of potential customers by not taking credit cards, particularly considering that they are basically a financing option for people

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Vycid> Mining hardware is essentially a business investment, not a personal purchase

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Vycid> Of course accepting cards opens you to up to all kind of bullshit like chargebacks. Then again, I am more inclined to trust companies that aren't afraid of chargebacks than those that clearly are

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Vycid> Crypto is trustless, pre-orders aren't. I will never again pay for a pre-order with crypto - learned my lesson there. But a credit card? Sure, I'm protected

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Patrick ManBearPig> I have no issue with them not accepting cards, but the point you are trying to make @Emmanuel would be stronger if they were not pricing the cards in fiat.
